headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome, ladies and gentlemen, to the Moody's Corporation Fourth Quarter Fiscal Year-End 2015 Earnings Conference Call. At this time, I would like to inform you that this conference is being recorded [Operator Instructions] I will now turn t
componenttext: Good day, and welcome, ladies and gentlemen, to the Moody's Corporation Fourth Quarter Fiscal Year-End 2015 Earnings Conference Call. At this time, I would like to inform you that this conference is being recorded [Operator Instructions] I will now turn the conference over to Salli Schwartz, global head of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us on this teleconference to discuss Moody's full year results for 2015 as well as our outlook for full year 2016. I am Salli Schwartz, Global Head of Investor Relations.This morning, Moody's rel
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us on this teleconference to discuss Moody's full year results for 2015 as well as our outlook for full year 2016. I am Salli Schwartz, Global Head of Investor Relations.
This morning, Moody's released its results for the fourth quarter and full year 2015 as well as our outlook for full-year 2016. The earnings press release and a presentation to accompany this teleconference are both available on our website at ir.moodys.com. Ray McDaniel, President and Chief Executive Officer of Moody's Corporation, will lead this morning's conference call. Also making prepared remarks on the call this morning is Linda Huber, Moody's Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.
Before we begin, I call your attention to the Safe Harbor language, which can be found toward the end of our earnings release. Today's remarks may contain forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. In accordance with the Act, I also direct your attention to the Management's Discussion and Analysis section and the risk factors discussed in our annual report on Form 10-K for the year-ended December 31, 2014, and in other SEC filings made by the company, which are available on our website and on the Securities and Exchange Commission's website. These, together with the safe harbor statements, set forth important factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those contained in any such forward-looking statements.
I would also like to point out that members of the media may be on the call this morning in a listen-only mode. I'll now turn the call over to Ray McDaniel.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Salli. Good morning, and thank you to everyone for joining today's call. I'll begin by summarizing Moody's fourth quarter and full-year 2015 results. Linda will follow with additional financial detail and operating highlights. I will then conclude
componenttext:
Thanks, Salli. Good morning, and thank you to everyone for joining today's call. I'll begin by summarizing Moody's fourth quarter and full-year 2015 results. Linda will follow with additional financial detail and operating highlights. I will then conclude with comments on our outlook for 2016. After our prepared remarks, we'll be happy to respond to your questions.
In the fourth quarter, Moody's delivered revenue of $866 [ph] million, a decline of 1% from the fourth quarter of 2014, but an increase of 2% on a constant-currency basis. Operating expense for the fourth quarter was $533 million, flat to the fourth quarter of 2014. Operating income was $333 million down 3% from the prior year period. And adjusted operating income, defined as operating income, less depreciation and amortization, was $362 million, also down 3% from the same period last year. Operating margin for the fourth quarter of 2015 was 38.5% and the adjusted operating margin was 41.8%. Diluted earnings per share of $1.09 was down 3% from the prior year period.
For full year 2015, Moody's achieved revenue and EPS growth for the 6 consecutive year despite difficult market conditions. Moody's revenue was $3.5 billion, an increase of 5% from the prior year or 9% on a constant-currency basis. Revenue at Moody's Investors Service was $2.3 billion, an increase of 3% from 2014 or 8% on a constant-currency basis. Revenue of Moody's Analytics was $1.2 billion, 8% higher than the prior year period or 12% on a constant-currency basis.
Operating expense for full year 2015 was $2 billion, up 6% from 2014. Foreign currency translation favorably impacted operating expense by 4%. Operating income of $1.5 billion increased 2% from 2014. Adjusted operating income of $1.6 billion increased 3% from the prior year period. Operating margin for full year 2015 was 42.3% and the adjusted operating margin was 45.5%. On a constant-currency basis and excluding our 2014 and 2015 acquisitions, operating margin and adjusted operating margin would have increased approximately 40 and 50 basis points respectively year-over-year.
Full year 2015 earnings per share of $4.63 increased from $4.61 in 2014. Non-GAAP EPS of $4.60 was up 9% from $4.21 in 2014. In both years, non-GAAP EPS excluded a $0.03 benefit from legacy tax matters. Full year 2014 non-GAAP EPS also excluded a $0.37 gain resulting from Moody's acquisition of a controlling interest in ICRA Ltd. in the second quarter of 2014.
I'll now turn the call over to you Linda to provide further commentary on our financial results and other updates.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ray. I'll begin with revenue at the company level. As Ray mentioned, Moody's total revenue for the fourth quarter decreased 1% to $866 million, but was up 2% on a constant-currency basis. U.S. revenue of $481 million was up 1% from the fourth quar
componenttext:
Thanks, Ray. I'll begin with revenue at the company level. As Ray mentioned, Moody's total revenue for the fourth quarter decreased 1% to $866 million, but was up 2% on a constant-currency basis. U.S. revenue of $481 million was up 1% from the fourth quarter of 2014. Non-U.S. revenue of $385 million is down 4%, but up 4% on a constant-currency basis. Revenue generated outside the U.S. represented 44% of Moody's total revenue. Recurring revenue of $446 million represented 51% of total revenue. 
Looking now at each of our businesses starting with Moody's Investors Service. Total MIS revenue for the quarter was $545 million, down 4% from the prior year period, but flat on a constant-currency basis. U.S. revenue decreased 2% to $338 million. Non-U.S. revenue of $206 million declined 7%, but was us up 2% on a constant-currency basis. Revenue generated outside the U.S. represented 38% of total earnings revenue.
Moving now to the lines of business for MIS. First, global corporate finance revenue in the fourth quarter was $246 million, down 7% from the prior year period or 4% on a constant-currency basis. This result reflected lower levels of non-U.S. investment grade and global speculative grade bond issuance, partially offset by improved levels of U.S. and European bank loan issuance. U.S. corporate finance revenue increased 1%, while non-U.S. revenue decreased 20%.
Second, global structure finance revenue for the fourth quarter was $114 million, down 4% from the prior year period, but flat on a constant-currency basis. Increased activity across most areas of structured finance partially offset lower CLO issuance. U.S. structured finance revenue was down 3% and non-U.S. revenue was down 9%.
Third, global financial institutions revenue of $92 million was up 8% from the prior year period or 13% on a constant-currency basis. This revenue was driven primarily by the U.S. insurance in European banking sector. U.S. financial institutions revenue was up 7% and non-U.S. revenue was up 8%. [ph] 
Fourth, global public project and infrastructure finance revenue of $85 million was down by 1% versus the prior year period or 2% on a constant-currency basis, primarily as a result of decreased U.S. public finance activity. U.S. public-private and infrastructure finance revenue was down 10%, while non-U.S. revenue was up 4%.
MIS other, which consists of non-rating revenue from Moody's majority-owned joint ventures ICRA and Korean Investors Service or KIS, contributed $7 million to MIS revenue in the fourth quarter compared to $8 million in the prior year period.
And turning now to Moody's Analytics. Global revenue for MA of $321 million was up 3% from the fourth quarter of 2014, or 6% on a constant-currency basis. U.S. revenue of $143 million was up 6% year-over-year. Non-U.S. revenue of $178 million was up 1% or 6% on a constant-currency basis. Revenue generated outside the U.S. represented 56% of total MA revenue.
And moving now to the lines of business for MA. First, global research data and analytics or RD&A revenue of $161 million was up 8% from the prior year period or 11% on constant-currency basis and represented 50% of total MA revenue. Growth was mainly due to strong new sales and product upgrades, coupled with record customer retention.  U.S. revenue was up 10% and non-U.S. revenue was up 5% or 11% on a constant-currency basis. 
Second, Enterprise Risk Solutions or ERS generated record revenue of $122 million and was up 1% from last year or 4% on a constant-currency basis. Growth was driven by strength in the credit assessment and originations and stress testing businesses. U.S. and non-U.S. ERS revenue were each up 1%. Trailing 12-month revenue in sales for ERS increased 14% and 11%, respectively. As we've noted in the past, due to the variable nature of product timing -- excuse me, project timing and completion, ERS revenue remains subject to quarterly volatility. 
Third, global professional services revenue of $38 million was down 10% from the prior year period or 6% on a constant-currency basis. This result was primarily due to lower net new business at Copal Amba as well as the of unfavorable impact of foreign exchange on the credentials and licensing business.
U.S. professional services revenue was down 7%, while non-U.S. revenue was down 11%.
And turning now to expenses. Moody's fourth quarter expense was $533 million, flat to the prior year period. An increase in compensation expense and merit increases in hiring was entirely offset by reduced incentive compensation. Foreign currency translation favorably impacted expense by 3%. Operating margin for the fourth quarter of 2015 of 38.5% was down from 39.3% in 2014. Adjusted operating margin of 41.8% was down from 42.4%. On a constant-currency basis and excluding our 2014 and 2015 acquisition, operating margin for the quarter would've been flat year-over-year and adjusted operating margin would have increased approximately 20 basis points.
Moody's effective tax rate for the fourth quarter was 29.4% compared with 28.1% for the prior year period. This increase was primarily due to a reduced percentage of income from lower tax rate jurisdictions primarily offset by the favorable resolution of tax audits.
And now I'll provide an update on capital allocation. On December 15, 2015, Moody's increase its quarterly dividend by 9% from $0.34 to $0.37 per share of common stock. Over the course of 2015, Moody's return $272 million to its shareholders via dividend payment. And with regard to share repurchase, during the fourth quarter of 2015, Moody's repurchased 2 [ph] million shares at a total cost of $193 million or an average cost of $100.09 per share, and issued 261,000 shares as part of this employee stock-based compensation plans. Full year 2015, Moody's repurchased 10.9 million shares or $1.1 billion or $101.14 per share and issued 32 -- excuse me, 3.2 million shares under employee stock-based compensation plans. Outstanding shares as of December 31, 2015, totaled 196.1 million shares down 4% from December 31, 2014. In December 2015, the Board of Directors authorized a $1 billion share repurchase program to commence following the completion of the existing program. Including this  incremental program as of December 31, 2015, Moody's had $1.5 billion of share repurchase authority remaining.
Turning now to Moody's leverage. In November 2015, Moody's issued $300 million of 5.25% senior unsecured notes due 2044. At the end of 2015, Moody's had $3.4 billion of outstanding debt and $1 billion of additional debt capacity available under its revolving credit facility. Total cash, cash equivalents and short-term investments at quarter end were $2.2 billion, up $555 million from December 31, 2014. As of December 31, 2015, approximately 68% of Moody's cash and cash equivalents were maintained outside of the U.S. Free cash flow for the full year of 2015 was $1.1 billion, up 13% for full year 2014, primarily due to changes in working capital.
And with that, I'll turn the call back over to Ray.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Linda. I'll conclude this morning's prepared comments by discussing our full year guidance for 2016. Moody's outlook for 2016 is based on assertions about many macroeconomic and capital market factors, including interest rates, foreign currency ex
componenttext:
Thanks, Linda. I'll conclude this morning's prepared comments by discussing our full year guidance for 2016. Moody's outlook for 2016 is based on assertions about many macroeconomic and capital market factors, including interest rates, foreign currency exchange rates, corporate profitability and business investment spending, mergers and acquisitions, consumer borrowing and securitization and the amount of debt issued. These essentials are subject to some degree of uncertainty and the results for the year could differ materially from our current outlook.
Moody's guidance assumes foreign currency translation for the British pound of $1.42 to GBP 1, and for the euro of $1.09 to the EUR 1. For all other currencies, Moody's assumes end of 2015 exchange rates.
Although we expect continued market volatility, we're projecting mid-single-digit percent revenue growth in 2016 as well as EPS of $4.75 to $4.85. Operating expense is expected to grow in the mid-single-digit expense range. Moody's projects and operating margin of approximately 42% and an adjusted operating margin of approximately 45%. The effective tax rate is expected to be 32% to 32.5%. 
2016 free cash flow is expected to be approximately $1.1 billion. Moody's expect share repurchases to be approximately $1 billion, subject to available cash, market conditions and other ongoing capital allocation decisions. Capital expenditures are projected to be $125 million to $135 million. Depreciation and amortization expense is expected to be approximately $130 [ph] million. 
For MIS, we expect 2016 revenue to grow in the mid-single-digit percent range. Both U.S. and non-U.S. MIS revenues are also expected to increase in the mid-single digit percent range.
Corporate finance revenue is expected to be flat. Structured finance revenue and public project and infrastructure finance revenue are each expected to grow in the high-single-digit percent range.
Financial institutions revenue is expected to grow in the mid-single-digit percent range. For MA, 2016 revenue is expected to increase in the mid-single-digit expense range. U.S. revenues is expected to go in the high-single-digit percent range and non-U.S. revenues is expected to be flat. Research, data and analytics revenues is projected to grow in the mid-single-digit percent range. Enterprise Risk Solutions revenues is expected to grow in the low-single-digit percent range following earlier-than-anticipated recognition of revenue in the fourth quarter of 2015. Professional services revenue is expected to decline in the low single-digit-percent range.
This concludes our prepared remarks, and joining us for the question-and-answer session is Michel Madalyn, President and Chief Operating Officer of Moody's Investors Service; and Mark Almeida, President of Moody's Analytics. We'll be pleased to take your questions.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Manav Patnaik from Barclays.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Manav Patnaik from Barclays.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question, which I'm sure you're anticipating, is just around the issuance and assumptions, particularly on the ratings business, could you just help give us a little bit more color on your underlying assumptions in terms of the global issuance, v
componenttext: My first question, which I'm sure you're anticipating, is just around the issuance and assumptions, particularly on the ratings business, could you just help give us a little bit more color on your underlying assumptions in terms of the global issuance, volume forecast and just maybe some of the moving pieces within those categories? Because it sounds like other than corporate finance, everything else is up nicely, which is sort of contrary to, I think, a lot of us were expecting. So I was hoping you could shed some color on those pieces there.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let me let Linda start this off, and if I have anything to add, I will.
componenttext: Sure. Let me let Linda start this off, and if I have anything to add, I will.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Manav, Salli is going to put up a new slide, which looks at the summation of the years the we've gotten from a number of investment banks, and we received in this on the afternoon of February 3. This is solely U.S. issuance information, though, and it is
componenttext: Manav, Salli is going to put up a new slide, which looks at the summation of the years the we've gotten from a number of investment banks, and we received in this on the afternoon of February 3. This is solely U.S. issuance information, though, and it is for both financial and non-financial leverage bonds and leverage loans. I'll go through each of the categories that  hopefully you can see up on the screen. Finally, I'll conclude by making some quick comments on the a European outlook. So firstly, investment-grade for January, we saw about $125 billion of issuance and it was the fourth highest volume month ever. However, $46 billion of that issuance came from 1 deal, the Ambet deal. We are encouraged by approximately $200 billion in the visible M&A pipeline, but volatility is impacting the pace of that issuance. So the pipeline is healthy, but we do seem to have some backup in the issuance pipeline. All-in funding costs are generally quite attractive. And lastly, the last point there in relation to M&A, shareholder-friendly  activities continue to be cited as the use of proceeds. So for the year, we see about $1.2 trillion in investment grade issuance in the U.S., which is about flat year-over-year. And that's a reasonable outlook that we can work with. Move onto the speculative-grade categories, high-yield bonds. January, about $7 billion of issuance. The leverage market was soft in December. That tone has continued into January and that makes us cautious. $35 billion is in the forward pipeline. And again, we see 2 classes of issuers, both with higher-quality speculative-grade names have access and those with lower ratings don't. Continue with headwinds coming from the commodities' volatility issue and default rate concerns. And last week, we saw in-flows back into high-yield bonds, which we haven't seen since the start of the year, which may indicate that perhaps we are establishing some stability, which will be helpful. So for the year, estimates range pretty widely on high-yield bond. About $240 billion is the sort of main number that we are seeing. That's down 15% year-over-year. Last year, I think we did about $275 billion and this numbers come down as we move to this point in time. Leverage loans, we saw $20 billion of issuance left in January and expecting $260 billion, which is down 10% for the year. So we've seen low volumes in the high-yield bond market and loans were about on pace with 2015. Leverage loan activity was consistent week-to-week in January and banks expects us to continue. Again, we can see $45 billion in the forward pipeline, but the timing of that is very much open to discussion. And uptick into fall could cause the loan space to be impacted negatively, but less so than the high-yield bond market. So investment-grade in summary in the U.S., about flat this year. High-yield bonds down 15 and leverage loans down about 10. Now in Europe, just in terms of what we're seeing there, generally we see broader uses to what can happen this year in terms of issuance. But generally, for Europe from the banks, we're seeing investment-grade up about 10%, high-yield bonds down about 10% and leverage loans up about 5%. On -- in terms of what we're seeing, the 10-year [ph] is quite tame at this point about 1 84, 1 85. And spreads on U.S. investment-grade bonds about 216 bps and in high yield about 765 bps. So spreads have widened with the 10 years come in, so we think all-in financing costs are relatively attractive. In Europe, the spread numbers are about 154 basis points for investment-grade, and for high-yield, about 538 basis points. So with that, I'll turn it over to Ray, and potentially, Michel may have some other color as well.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: The only thing I would add is with respect to new rating mandates. We did have a healthy pace of new mandates throughout the year in 2015 coming in at about 770 new mandates and that has continued to be a healthy pipeline early this year. So there's obvio
componenttext: The only thing I would add is with respect to new rating mandates. We did have a healthy pace of new mandates throughout the year in 2015 coming in at about 770 new mandates and that has continued to be a healthy pipeline early this year. So there's obviously going to be decisions by potential new issuers about when and if they want to get in the market. And I agree with Linda's comments, some stability will encourage them in. But it's -- we take that as a good sign in terms of the pipeline of new activity, fresh names.

componenttext: Okay, fair enough. And so just one follow-up. In terms of just clarifying your mid-single-digit guidance for the total company and then for the division as well. What is the exact FX impact you're assuming for the total? and I presume MA has a bigger hit numbers?

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: The overall impact of FX will be about 1% unfavorable on revenue and about 2% favorable on the expense. I don't have the breakdown by the individual business units but that's for the overall corporation.
componenttext: The overall impact of FX will be about 1% unfavorable on revenue and about 2% favorable on the expense. I don't have the breakdown by the individual business units but that's for the overall corporation.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Manav, just to sort of put a stake in on it for you, we looked at -- we budgeted, as we said, at 1 0 9 on the euro. The euro's effect moved up a bit from there, and $1.42 on the pound. The net impact is  the euro moves down from 1 0 9 by about a cent, tha
componenttext: Manav, just to sort of put a stake in on it for you, we looked at -- we budgeted, as we said, at 1 0 9 on the euro. The euro's effect moved up a bit from there, and $1.42 on the pound. The net impact is  the euro moves down from 1 0 9 by about a cent, that hits us about a cent in EPS. But as we said, since we finished putting this together, in fact, the euro has appreciated versus the dollar. And I don't know if anyone else has any more specific comments.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Andre Benjamin with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Andre Benjamin with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My first question is, I guess, the 1 area you didn't talk about in that detail or run down is the structured finance market. So I'm just wondering what you're seeing that makes you assume that accelerates to high single digits from mid-singl
componenttext: Good morning. My first question is, I guess, the 1 area you didn't talk about in that detail or run down is the structured finance market. So I'm just wondering what you're seeing that makes you assume that accelerates to high single digits from mid-single-digit guidance last year, and reported? And then how much of that is being driven by U.S. versus the euro?

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. We were really looking at strength in multiple areas of structured finance in 2016, with an offset coming from the CLO sector, which we think is going to be softer. And really, I think the most important driver and structured side is the refinancing
componenttext: Sure. We were really looking at strength in multiple areas of structured finance in 2016, with an offset coming from the CLO sector, which we think is going to be softer. And really, I think the most important driver and structured side is the refinancing that has to occur for commercial real estate. So we expect to have a strong year for CMBS in particular, but also we expect to continue to see growth in the asset-backed and [indiscernible] mortgage-backed securities sectors. That is -- and that improvement, we anticipate in really all geographies. Probably stronger in the U.S. expect for the CLO area than in Europe, but we do expect to see growth around the world.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then you guys have always done a very good job of controlling costs and delivering on the margin. I guess, no one has the perfect crystal ball on issuance for the year, just a view on issuance changes to the upside or, God forbid, to the down side, ho
componenttext: And then you guys have always done a very good job of controlling costs and delivering on the margin. I guess, no one has the perfect crystal ball on issuance for the year, just a view on issuance changes to the upside or, God forbid, to the down side, how should we think about how much room left you have there to continue to manage costs since you've already run the shift so tight so far?

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Andre. A couple of comments. I would note that in the fourth quarter, expenses were flat. And with incentive comp, we offset any other increase in compensation. So we're pretty aggressive about managing expenses, as you have noted. Just a couple of
componenttext: Sure, Andre. A couple of comments. I would note that in the fourth quarter, expenses were flat. And with incentive comp, we offset any other increase in compensation. So we're pretty aggressive about managing expenses, as you have noted. Just a couple of comments. If, in fact, the top line does pick up, we get pretty good operating leverage about those increases in the top line. The only incremental piece that we really need to pay will be incentive compensation. So we look at maybe $0.60, $0.70 on a dollar of revenue, so that is very helpful. As you pointed out, the top line is the tricky part for this year and we're looking at margin being about flat. We finished last year at 42 3 and we're saying the we'll be about flat this year. To be perfectly honest, it's a little tough for us to have the margin come in exactly at where we expect it to, but we are reinvesting in our business and we think flat margin is fine. From an FX-adjusted basis, we're planning for expenses to increase by about $100 million in 2016 and those are about evenly split between 3 different things: The first is the role forward of the hiring we did in 2015; second will be the hiring we're doing in 2016; and the third will really be around technology and real estate changes that we're making. On the technology piece, we are investing in our system. Cyber security is a piece of that, which I think every financial corporation is looking at right now. And then we do have a bit heavier than usual real estate these. I think you've probably seen, we've taken 2 floors over at One World Trade Center at very attractive rates and the 52nd floor here in the center at 7 World Trade, also a very attractive rate. But we really need to get those new floors online here and there will be some expense associated with that. So nothing the exciting. But to draw the top line, which we think is pretty healthy, given what other companies are putting up. To drive mid-single-digit we do need to spend some money and our plans are modest, but we are thinking revenue will be about flat. I don't know if Ray or the division has anything more to say on that.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. The only reminder I would make is that our reaction to cyclical changes is going to be less material than anything we see happening that's more structural in nature. So we do see structural changes in our market, which we are going to react more aggre
componenttext: No. The only reminder I would make is that our reaction to cyclical changes is going to be less material than anything we see happening that's more structural in nature. So we do see structural changes in our market, which we are going to react more aggressively on the expense side.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Alex Kramm with UBS.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Alex Kramm with UBS.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Coming back to the guidance for a second, can you talk about the recurring fees on the rating agencies a little bit? First of all, what are you expecting there? But more importantly, when you talk about monitoring fees, I think that's about the biggest pi
componenttext: Coming back to the guidance for a second, can you talk about the recurring fees on the rating agencies a little bit? First of all, what are you expecting there? But more importantly, when you talk about monitoring fees, I think that's about the biggest piece. How should we be thinking about that from a cyclically challenged perspective in the base one? I guess, what I'm trying to say this if there are defaults in the high-yield market that are picking up, if issuance slows, at what point do monitoring fees start to kind of like roll off? And how should we be thinking about that?

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Alex, let -- maybe Ray and I can take a start to that and then we'll ask Michel to think about it. The monitoring fees are the most constant part of our business and the average life of debt right now is about 7 years. So they move very slowly. But we do
componenttext: Alex, let -- maybe Ray and I can take a start to that and then we'll ask Michel to think about it. The monitoring fees are the most constant part of our business and the average life of debt right now is about 7 years. So they move very slowly. But we do have price increases on those fees year-over-year on new mandates that we bring on and we would expect that, that line would move to the upside and would move gradually. I'm not sure that the fault would have much of an impact on that, there are really 2 different things. But I'll ask Ray for [indiscernible]

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It would not be material. We have -- I think, as Linda mentioned, we have a trailing 12-month rate for high-yield at a little over 3% and we're expecting that to increase by year-end 2016 to about 4.5%. That 1.2%, 1.3% difference in default rates is
componenttext: Yes. It would not be material. We have -- I think, as Linda mentioned, we have a trailing 12-month rate for high-yield at a little over 3% and we're expecting that to increase by year-end 2016 to about 4.5%. That 1.2%, 1.3% difference in default rates is not going to be material to the overall monitoring fees we get in, which obviously not include not only the high-yield sector, but investment-grade sector and noncorporate monitoring fees as well.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then secondly, this is a small part of your business, but I was a little surprised in the professional services guidance. I mean, it seems like last year, there was a -- the tough comps from shutting down some businesses. Having that down
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then secondly, this is a small part of your business, but I was a little surprised in the professional services guidance. I mean, it seems like last year, there was a -- the tough comps from shutting down some businesses. Having that down again this year, anything else going on? Is it just a very tough environment? Or why is it not accelerating now that you can right size the business, it seems?

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Alex, I'll take a shot on that for a couple and then I'll turn it over to Mark on the training business. So what's behind the Copal Amba, we had attrition of 1 large customer account. Now as you're aware, you're quite aware, Alex, the global banks a
componenttext: Sure. Alex, I'll take a shot on that for a couple and then I'll turn it over to Mark on the training business. So what's behind the Copal Amba, we had attrition of 1 large customer account. Now as you're aware, you're quite aware, Alex, the global banks are having some challenges right now and some of them are responding to that by increasing headcount at Copal Amba. But 1 large bank went the other way so we have to lap that. We're working very hard on restructuring the sales function and broadening away from the global banks in terms of the customers that we serve and that's going well. We are encouraged by early progress there. But we did make very good strides integrating the business last year. We've really ramped up our internal efforts of having Copal Amba support both Moody's Analytics and the rating agency, so we're very encouraged by that. But as we said, we did have 1 large bank go the other way and we've got to work through that. Maybe Mark, wants to talk a little bit about training.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Alex, in the training business, we had a very good year in '15 on the sales side in training, which is going to result in much better revenue out of that business in '16. So that's the good news. We still have a pretty sizable FX hit in the training
componenttext: Sure. Alex, in the training business, we had a very good year in '15 on the sales side in training, which is going to result in much better revenue out of that business in '16. So that's the good news. We still have a pretty sizable FX hit in the training business though, which is going to hold down the reported growth rate. But I think we've got some -- we've got much more strength on the training piece of professional services in '16 than we saw in '15.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Peter Appert with Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Peter Appert with Piper Jaffray.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So maybe for Mark, the strength in the enterprise risk resolutions business was noteworthy, I know you point out that some of it was timing, but this is the second year in a row that we got this timing business, so I'm wondering why you are not a little m
componenttext: So maybe for Mark, the strength in the enterprise risk resolutions business was noteworthy, I know you point out that some of it was timing, but this is the second year in a row that we got this timing business, so I'm wondering why you are not a little more upbeat in terms of the revenue growth potential there?

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm not more upbeat about '16 because we had 2 benefit years of benefit from timing. We had a big revenue recognition event in the fourth quarter. We knew that was coming, we just didn't know when it was going to come and it happened to come through in th
componenttext: I'm not more upbeat about '16 because we had 2 benefit years of benefit from timing. We had a big revenue recognition event in the fourth quarter. We knew that was coming, we just didn't know when it was going to come and it happened to come through in the late part of '15 rather than in early '16. So that was good news for '15, but of course, it impacts the '16 outlook. The other thing we have going on, Peter, is that we continue to take some FX hits as we roll into '16 as well, so we're a bit modest in our expectations for ERS in '16. I'll just remind you that over the last -- well, we had 1% growth in the fourth quarter in '15, but that was off of a very strong 42% growth in the fourth quarter of '14. So that was pretty good. If you look at the prior 7 quarters, 4of those quarters, we came in at 24% or better and the other 3 were 12%, 13% and 14%. So we had a pretty long run now of very strong growth in ERS business and we're just going to settle out a little bit in '16 as we kind of get -- as the timing normalizes, if you will.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: What does that suggest then, Mark, in terms of the sustainable growth rate in that business?
componenttext: What does that suggest then, Mark, in terms of the sustainable growth rate in that business?

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: We continue to feel very good about the sustainability in the business. Again, if you look on the sales side, sales growth was very healthy in 2015 despite our having taken about 2 points of FX hit. The other thing I'll just remind you, and we've spoken a
componenttext: We continue to feel very good about the sustainability in the business. Again, if you look on the sales side, sales growth was very healthy in 2015 despite our having taken about 2 points of FX hit. The other thing I'll just remind you, and we've spoken about this before, but we've told you we are deemphasizing the implementation services business. That's the relatively low margin piece of the ERS business, which has been driving a lot of top line growth for us, but hasn't been doing much on the margin. So as we backed away from that, we're going to give up a couple of points of growth on the top line to set ourselves up for a more profitable growth going forward. And that's a little bit, again, if these plans work out the way we've organized them, that's going to be again a bit of a onetime hit to top line growth in '16, but should set us up for good growth going forward and more profitable growth going forward.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on that front, Mark, you've talked in the past about this mid-20% margin target. Margins are up just a little bit in '15, so is the mid-20% target still relevant? Will we see progress towards that goal in '16? And then I'm asking this partly in the con
componenttext: So on that front, Mark, you've talked in the past about this mid-20% margin target. Margins are up just a little bit in '15, so is the mid-20% target still relevant? Will we see progress towards that goal in '16? And then I'm asking this partly in the context of Linda's earlier comment about sort of being comfortable with flattish margins. Are you backing away at all from the expectation of margin upside in Analytics?

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as we've said, we viewed the margin expansion program for MA as something that is going to take place over several years. We view it as a marathon rather than a sprint. So we still have those plans in effect, we have there a variety of things that w
componenttext: Well, as we've said, we viewed the margin expansion program for MA as something that is going to take place over several years. We view it as a marathon rather than a sprint. So we still have those plans in effect, we have there a variety of things that we're doing that we believe will position us to run a more profitable business. The other thing I would note, however, Peter, just to keep in mind in the context of Linda's comments is that as MA grows and grows faster than the rating agency, as we saw in '15, we do attract more corporate overhead. So we've also -- we've got that offset going on as well. But nevertheless, our plans for driving more profit out of the business are still intact. We're executing on those plans and we feel good about what we're doing.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Bill Bird with FBR.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Bill Bird with FBR.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just as a follow-up, Mark, I was wondering if you could size the timing benefit to revenues in ERS on the deliverable that was referenced? And secondly, just wondering if you're seeing any change in client behavior in terms of their willingness to buy, gi
componenttext: Just as a follow-up, Mark, I was wondering if you could size the timing benefit to revenues in ERS on the deliverable that was referenced? And secondly, just wondering if you're seeing any change in client behavior in terms of their willingness to buy, given the context of world volatility?

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: As for the first piece, it was about $20 million that we pulled from '16 into '15. So just to give you a sense of the scale of that thing. With respect to your second question, the short answer is no. Demand continues to be very healthy. We really haven't
componenttext: As for the first piece, it was about $20 million that we pulled from '16 into '15. So just to give you a sense of the scale of that thing. With respect to your second question, the short answer is no. Demand continues to be very healthy. We really haven't observed any meaningful change in customer behavior. We haven't observed sales cycle lengthening or anything like that. The sales pipeline is very, very healthy. So honestly, I can't say that we've observed anything that would suggest that what we're reading about in the newspapers is impacting demand for what we're selling.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just as a follow-on, can you give us a sense of just a size, rough size of the implementation business that are deemphasizing?
componenttext: And just as a follow-on, can you give us a sense of just a size, rough size of the implementation business that are deemphasizing?

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think we've disclosed that in the past. We talked about -- if you think about that as kind of the nonrecurring portion of the ERS business, or at least a substantial piece of it, you can look at it in those terms. And I think we talked about that.
componenttext: I don't think we've disclosed that in the past. We talked about -- if you think about that as kind of the nonrecurring portion of the ERS business, or at least a substantial piece of it, you can look at it in those terms. And I think we talked about that.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I would also just add that this is not -- we're not stepping away completely from implementation services. We will still do some of that, because it supports the product sales. So it's difficult for us to give you a precise number on that, because we
componenttext: And I would also just add that this is not -- we're not stepping away completely from implementation services. We will still do some of that, because it supports the product sales. So it's difficult for us to give you a precise number on that, because we don't know exactly what that interaction between implementation services and product sales will continue to be.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's exactly right. To be clear, we're not taking implementation services to 0. We're just not -- we're planning to keep it flat in '16. But as Ray observed, and he's quite right, we don't have complete control over that. A lot of that will be down
componenttext: Yes, that's exactly right. To be clear, we're not taking implementation services to 0. We're just not -- we're planning to keep it flat in '16. But as Ray observed, and he's quite right, we don't have complete control over that. A lot of that will be down to what the customers want and what we think is the right thing to do in order to drive growth in the licenses and subscription sides of the business.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Tim McHugh with William Blair and Company.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Tim McHugh with William Blair and Company.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016

componenttext: Yes. I want to ask in emerging markets. Just in the past, you guys -- basically, my math added almost a point to growth in the last couple of years just in general. Obviously, choppier markets there. Can you talk about what's the outlook there? Have you seen a slowdown in your ability to add new mandates and grow in those markets?

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Michel, do you want to comment on the emerging market?
componenttext: Michel, do you want to comment on the emerging market?

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, clearly, these markets have been, as you know subject to a fair amount of stress. And we've seen impact negatively in Latin America, post Petrobras. And in Asia actually, we have -- we continue to have a good pipeline of new mandates coming
componenttext: Yes. I think, clearly, these markets have been, as you know subject to a fair amount of stress. And we've seen impact negatively in Latin America, post Petrobras. And in Asia actually, we have -- we continue to have a good pipeline of new mandates coming out of China notably, although the region clearly is subject to some of the economic pressures that you are very familiar with. [indiscernible] emerging market that's really essential -- the Gulf pace and Middle East, and those of small businesses, really.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And as we think about price, I know you target 3% to 4% over time, but I guess, in the context of the current macro, can you get -- I mean, is it still safe for us to think about 3 or 4 points of growth in price and the type of environment the we're
componenttext: Okay. And as we think about price, I know you target 3% to 4% over time, but I guess, in the context of the current macro, can you get -- I mean, is it still safe for us to think about 3 or 4 points of growth in price and the type of environment the we're expecting for 2016?

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We have built in pricing assumptions for 2016 that support our outlook, so we are still able to factor in price. As I've said in the past, some of the price does relate to issuance volumes. So if we change bond fees and bonds are not issued, then cha
componenttext: Yes. We have built in pricing assumptions for 2016 that support our outlook, so we are still able to factor in price. As I've said in the past, some of the price does relate to issuance volumes. So if we change bond fees and bonds are not issued, then changing the bond fee doesn't really matter. So we're going have to see what the mix is in terms of issuance and how that aligns with where we feel we are adding particular value and think that we can adjust pricing. So I would stick with our long-term comment that we think we can get 3 to 4 points on average and we'll see this year based on volume.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Craig Huber with Huber Research partners.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Craig Huber with Huber Research partners.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ray, you talked about the default rates for high yield, I believe you said in the U.S. 3% going to 4.5% in the year out. What are those numbers [indiscernible] if you exclude the energy sectors?
componenttext: Ray, you talked about the default rates for high yield, I believe you said in the U.S. 3% going to 4.5% in the year out. What are those numbers [indiscernible] if you exclude the energy sectors?

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you exclude energy, as of year-end 2015, the 12-month default rate was actually quite low. It was about 1.6%, so it's -- and we don't have a -- don't publish a speculative-grade forecast by industry. But you can look at that 1.6 ex oil and gas and meta
componenttext: If you exclude energy, as of year-end 2015, the 12-month default rate was actually quite low. It was about 1.6%, so it's -- and we don't have a -- don't publish a speculative-grade forecast by industry. But you can look at that 1.6 ex oil and gas and metals and mining as compared to the overall default rate of 3.2 as of December.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then also Ray, just in general, when you look at the corporate get market out there built in the U.S. and Europe, are you seeing anything out there [indiscernible] that makes you think there's too much debt in the system out there? Whether the coverag
componenttext: And then also Ray, just in general, when you look at the corporate get market out there built in the U.S. and Europe, are you seeing anything out there [indiscernible] that makes you think there's too much debt in the system out there? Whether the coverage ratio, relative EBITDA, what have you, relative GDP?

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't say we've seen anything that would characterize as a bubble. There obviously are some parts of the market that have more leverage than others, and obviously, there is stress in the energy, metals and mining sectors. But looking at the market mo
componenttext: I wouldn't say we've seen anything that would characterize as a bubble. There obviously are some parts of the market that have more leverage than others, and obviously, there is stress in the energy, metals and mining sectors. But looking at the market more broadly, there's nothing that I would say we've identified as being a particular red flag.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then also in your guidance for ratings up mid-single-digit revenue for the year, would you characterize that as back half of the year weighted? And if so, are you also expecting more than normal pull forward of any debt issuance from the refinan
componenttext: Okay. And then also in your guidance for ratings up mid-single-digit revenue for the year, would you characterize that as back half of the year weighted? And if so, are you also expecting more than normal pull forward of any debt issuance from the refinancing wall in 2017 coming into the back half of 2016? I mean, how do you sort of see this either playing out in terms of the cadence of the revenue growth or lack thereof as the year progressses to get to that mid-single-digit number for ratings?

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I felt for a while that the second half of their offers more potential probably than the first half of the year, in part because we do have the refinancing build from 2017 through 2019 coming closer on the horizon. And also just because we've been th
componenttext: Yes, I felt for a while that the second half of their offers more potential probably than the first half of the year, in part because we do have the refinancing build from 2017 through 2019 coming closer on the horizon. And also just because we've been through a recent period of really strong volatility in the markets, and I think markets looking for more stability in energy and seeing where spreads settle, that's going to encourage -- the stability itself will encourage issuance in addition to the refinancing walls that will be coming closer.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. My last question, Linda, I'd like to particularly ask you, can you break down the revenues by your 4 major categories within ratings? High yield versus bank loan versus investment grade in the fourth quarter?
componenttext: Okay. My last question, Linda, I'd like to particularly ask you, can you break down the revenues by your 4 major categories within ratings? High yield versus bank loan versus investment grade in the fourth quarter?

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Craig, we can do that. So we're doing Q4 2015 and the first line of business is corporate finance. So we're going to look at 4 different areas, investment-grade, spec-grade, bank loans and other. The total revenue for this category for the fourth qu
componenttext: Sure, Craig, we can do that. So we're doing Q4 2015 and the first line of business is corporate finance. So we're going to look at 4 different areas, investment-grade, spec-grade, bank loans and other. The total revenue for this category for the fourth quarter was $246 million. So investment grade was $71 million, about flat from the fourth quarter last year in terms of percentages, a little bit down on dollar basis. Spec-grade decreased to $26.5 million from last year's $34.1 million in the fourth quarter. Bank loans interestingly increased in the fourth quarter 2015 to $44 million from last year's $37 million, and bank loans were 18% of [ph] this total corporate line. Other was $104.4 million, down from last year's $112 million and represented 42% of the split. And again corporates represented 45% off the MIS revenues for the fourth quarter of '15. Moving onto structured, we'll go through 5 different lines. The total for structured was $114 million in 2015. First, we'll look at ABS and that was about $24 million, up a little bit from last year's $22 million. Second is residential mortgage-backed securities, $23 million, up a bit from last year's $20 million. Commercial real estate, $37.5 million, up from last year's about $36 million. And structured credit at about $30 million, down from last year's $40 million. And others, pretty negligible. So again that all sums to $114 million. If we move on to FIG, total's about $92 million for the fourth quarter. And we'll look at banking insurance, managed investments and the other. So banking's about $61 million, about flat from last year's $60 million; insurance at about $24 million is up nicely from last year's $19 million; managed investments at $4.4 million was flat to last year. And other at 2 [indiscernible] was also flat to last year. And then lastly, we go to PPIF. Total is $85 million here. We've got 3 categories, which include PFG and sovereign first, which is about $46 million. Last year we're about $48 million on this line for the fourth quarter. Project and infrastructure is the second category. About $40 million here, which is down from last year's $42 million and then other is negligible, really, in both periods. So I think that's the total split of the big categories, Craig. Is that -- did that get it done for your?

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Perfect. Thank you.
componenttext: Yes. Perfect. Thank you.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Doug Arthur with Huber Research.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Doug Arthur with Huber Research.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Linda, you mentioned that you dropped incentive comp or controlled it pretty aggressively in the fourth quarter. Can you give us some idea of the numbers there?
componenttext: Linda, you mentioned that you dropped incentive comp or controlled it pretty aggressively in the fourth quarter. Can you give us some idea of the numbers there?

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So for fourth quarter of 2015, incentive compensation was 13% of our total comp expenses of $336 million for the quarter, which was just about flat to what we did for last year, but the components were quite different. So this year, we put up $44 mi
componenttext: Sure. So for fourth quarter of 2015, incentive compensation was 13% of our total comp expenses of $336 million for the quarter, which was just about flat to what we did for last year, but the components were quite different. So this year, we put up $44 million in the fourth quarter for incentive compensation. Last year, we put up $53 million. So this was a delta of almost $9 million. The fourth quarter of '15 didn't come in as strong as we might have liked, and therefore, the incentive compensation accrual backed off by quite a bit. Also what was interesting is last year, we did have $7 million of profit sharing in the fourth quarter. And for this fourth quarter, we did not have any profit sharing, and so that saved another $7 million. So really, $16 million there, a reduction in those 2 lines. Now on salaries and benefits, we did move up from $255 million last year to about $272 million this year. So again that increase in salaries and benefits, that was completely offset by what happened with the incentive compensation. Stock-based comp was about flat at $20.5 million, so not much going on differently there. But I think what we want to demonstrate here, Doug, is we pulled the incentive comp lever pretty hard if things are a little bit weaker than we think. And the first reduction there goes to, unfortunately, to the employees. So that's how we've handled it. I hope that's helpful.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Bill Warmington with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Bill Warmington with Wells Fargo.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I have a question for you on MIS. If you look at total MIS growth rate on a 2-year basis, and by that, I mean, you just take the growth rate of a quarter and add it the growth rate of the quarter a year ago. It is then moving at about mid-teens for the
componenttext: So I have a question for you on MIS. If you look at total MIS growth rate on a 2-year basis, and by that, I mean, you just take the growth rate of a quarter and add it the growth rate of the quarter a year ago. It is then moving at about mid-teens for the first 3 quarters of 2015. And then the fourth quarter, just reported, it dropped to about 4%. And if we assume -- and that 4% would line up with the guidance for MIS for 2016. If we assume that, that 4% to 2-year comp is kind of the target for 2016 and we go through by the quarters in keeping that 4%, it would imply Q1 would be about -- down about 10%, Q2 up about 2%, [ph] Q3 up about 4% and Q4 up about 7% to 8%. And I just wanted to run that by the [indiscernible] that methodology was okay? Or maybe you could suggest a better one in terms of looking at how to think about the progression of MIS throughout the year, given uncertainties of the market?

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bill, it's Ray. I have to be honest, I didn't quite keep up with all the math. But maybe what I can do to be helpful is to remind listeners that our revenue typically follows a sawtooth pattern, with the second and fourth quarters being stronger, first an
componenttext: Bill, it's Ray. I have to be honest, I didn't quite keep up with all the math. But maybe what I can do to be helpful is to remind listeners that our revenue typically follows a sawtooth pattern, with the second and fourth quarters being stronger, first and third quarters being softer. We did not see that pattern strongly in 2015 because of weakness in the fourth quarter, and I would anticipate, at this point in time, that we would be back to more of the traditional sawtooth going into 2016. So second and fourth quarters. And I would also anticipate that as I mentioned a little while ago, that we may see momentum picking up in the second half of the year this year.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016

componenttext: A couple of housekeeping items. I just wanted to just double check the organic constant currency growth was for company -- I know that we don't have a lot coming in from acquisitions with [indiscernible] and corporate, but I thought I'd ask for that.

componenttext: Yes. For MA, we were -- as reported, we were up 8% for the year. Organic constant currency would have been almost 10%.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't have them in front of me, but they were about 1,000 each year. So we were down from this peak years. And those were peak years, those were record years for new mandates. But the 770 compares quite favorably to years prior to 2013. So we're sort of
componenttext: I don't have them in front of me, but they were about 1,000 each year. So we were down from this peak years. And those were peak years, those were record years for new mandates. But the 770 compares quite favorably to years prior to 2013. So we're sort of in the middle range at this point between the peak and historical run rate.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016

componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Warren Gardiner with Evercore Investments.

componenttext: So I just -- I know M&A kind of drive the whole kind of services, and we saw -- I kind of thought in 2015, it was a nice benefit to revenue for ratings, but I was just curious if we stay in kind of a choppier backdrop, how you guys potentially benefit, if at all from restructuring-related services?

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Warren, it's Linda. I think you had said M&A activity. I'm assuming you mean for the economy as a whole has been helpful to us in terms of bond issuance, and you wanted us to comment on that. I'm not sure we were quite clear on the second part of your que
componenttext: Warren, it's Linda. I think you had said M&A activity. I'm assuming you mean for the economy as a whole has been helpful to us in terms of bond issuance, and you wanted us to comment on that. I'm not sure we were quite clear on the second part of your question there.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was just saying sort of additional services related to M&A kind of helped you guys this year, and I was wondering if that was somewhat true with respect to potentially restructuring if things were to get choppier?
componenttext: I was just saying sort of additional services related to M&A kind of helped you guys this year, and I was wondering if that was somewhat true with respect to potentially restructuring if things were to get choppier?

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. M&A has been a wind in our back. And as I noted earlier, we've got about $200 million in the investment grade M&A pipeline and we've got about $35 billion in the high-yield pipeline that's kind of sitting there waiting to move. We've seen this situa
componenttext: Sure. M&A has been a wind in our back. And as I noted earlier, we've got about $200 million in the investment grade M&A pipeline and we've got about $35 billion in the high-yield pipeline that's kind of sitting there waiting to move. We've seen this situation before, wherein our risk-off part of the market. We had a lot volatility. But these pipelines believe that eventually. We'll wait and see where things go with the Fed potentially in March. But when we can see the pipelines there it does give us some view to be a bit more optimistic. The timing us the tricky thing and that's why at Moody's, we don't give quarterly guidance because it's very difficult to predict. But we do expect that M&A is continuing and that a lot of companies have bridge stones in place for refinancing, and eventually they're going to have to be taken out. So it's a matter of when. And I'll let Ray talk more about that.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to come to issuance a different way to kind of close out the call. As far as swing factors are concerned on the issuance question for what the outlook could be for 2016, what do you think the most important swing factor is? Is it stability? I
componenttext: Just wanted to come to issuance a different way to kind of close out the call. As far as swing factors are concerned on the issuance question for what the outlook could be for 2016, what do you think the most important swing factor is? Is it stability? I assume you're expecting 1 or 2 interest rate hikes. Is it M&A? Is it the back half of the year? I'm just wondering as an outsider, what we should think about as kind of being the most important thing to look at?

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's, first of all, some stability. So that companies feel that they have visibility in what their issuance would look like. Obviously, rates and spreads are relevant. I don't think that movement on the short-term rates is going to be particularly
componenttext: I think it's, first of all, some stability. So that companies feel that they have visibility in what their issuance would look like. Obviously, rates and spreads are relevant. I don't think that movement on the short-term rates is going to be particularly impactful. It's really looking more than long term rates for the bond issuance. And it also has to do with economic momentum in the economy and refinancing needs. So if we had relatively widespreads or volatility in the market and we don't see a lot of economic momentum to encourage capital expenditures and business expansion, and we don't have refinancing needs, then issuance is going to be more subdued. But when that combination of factors starts to come into better alignment, stability spreads narrowing and the need to refinance, either for business expansion -- or the need to finance, either for refinancing or business expansion, that's the virtuous cycle.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And let me just comment a little bit more on our various sectors here, and Michel maybe helpful to this discussion. So we said for investment-grade issuance looks to be about flat. In high-yield bonds for 2015, we did $183 million of revenue. That's about
componenttext: And let me just comment a little bit more on our various sectors here, and Michel maybe helpful to this discussion. So we said for investment-grade issuance looks to be about flat. In high-yield bonds for 2015, we did $183 million of revenue. That's about 5% of the corporation's revenue. Again, high-yield in 2015, only 5% of the corporation's revenue. Bank loans, a little over $200 million, about 6% of the corporation's revenue. And in the fourth quarter of '15, as I had said to Craig, our spec grade revenue was down to $26.5 million. We fought very hard about high-yield for 2016 and we think that the Q4 run rate 2015, we hope, is low. So we have reduced our high-yield view, we've been very thoughtful about that, but we don't think it's going to be quite as bad as it was in the fourth quarter of 2015. We're watching this very carefully, its probably the trickiest line we've had to work earlier. And I might invite Michel to say a little bit more about his thoughts on that, because that really has been, I think, the biggest challenge for us in terms of how we're thinking about 2016. Michel, you want to add some color.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, what I would say is when you think about investment grade, I mean, the fact that Ray mentioned and you discussed earlier, which is M&A, the economy are clearly the key to [indiscernible] here. I think, when you go to our [indiscernible] the i
componenttext: Yes. I mean, what I would say is when you think about investment grade, I mean, the fact that Ray mentioned and you discussed earlier, which is M&A, the economy are clearly the key to [indiscernible] here. I think, when you go to our [indiscernible] the impact of market sentiment and the overall -- the spread and the risk-on, risk-off sort of changes we see are probably much more impactful and, therefore, much more difficult -- is much more difficult project that they should expect. And there, it's sort of idiosyncratic factors are playing a bigger role.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016

componenttext: Got it. And just building on it, I'm going to take a crack on this question because I know it's a difficult one. Is there anything in particular you'd point out when you went to your guidance process this year versus other years that you did differently that might shed some light on how comfortable we can become with the issuance guidance for 2016?

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, the short answer is no. We really didn't do anything differently than we normally do. It's a combination of internal worth and speaking with other market participants to get their consensus of use and we build our forecast off of that.
componenttext: I guess, the short answer is no. We really didn't do anything differently than we normally do. It's a combination of internal worth and speaking with other market participants to get their consensus of use and we build our forecast off of that.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016

componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Denny Galindo with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to just real quickly since I've been on the air for a while. I wanted to talk a little bit about that high-yield line item. It does seem like it might be a swing factor this year. Could that actually benefit if you had this big wall of investm
componenttext: Just wanted to just real quickly since I've been on the air for a while. I wanted to talk a little bit about that high-yield line item. It does seem like it might be a swing factor this year. Could that actually benefit if you had this big wall of investment-grade maturities in 2016 and 2017 and some of that's downgraded into high yield? Is that something kind of -- it's almost like a fallen angel of that? Is that something that could end up helping year in the high-yield line item this year? Or maybe you could comment on that idea?

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I guess, it would help the high-yield line item. It wouldn't help the investment-grade line item. But I think you're -- the serious part of an answer to your question would be that we really wouldn't expect a material commercial difference based on
componenttext: Well, I guess, it would help the high-yield line item. It wouldn't help the investment-grade line item. But I think you're -- the serious part of an answer to your question would be that we really wouldn't expect a material commercial difference based on an investment-grade names falling into spec grade range. We have both frequent issuer pricing agreements and we have transaction-based pricing. And so it's possible to see more frequent issuers dropping into the spec grade range, but I think that would be very much in the margin and would not impact our -- the financial part of our business as opposed to the analytics.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then lastly, someone did ask about restructuring and it's kind of the credit assessment part of these, so that are kind of minimal as it relates to M&A. Are there any additional revenue streams you would benefit from if they had
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then lastly, someone did ask about restructuring and it's kind of the credit assessment part of these, so that are kind of minimal as it relates to M&A. Are there any additional revenue streams you would benefit from if they had like to distress debt exchange or default? Or anything that occurs in a more difficult credit environment that doesn't typically occur in a more favorable credit environment? Is that a meaningful amount or does that move the needle at all? Or is it relatively small as well?

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think it's really, as Linda was pointing out, that to the extent that having companies in distress drives a portion of the mergers and acquisition activity we see in the market, that can be helpful in terms of the financing some of that M&A. But oth
componenttext: No. I think it's really, as Linda was pointing out, that to the extent that having companies in distress drives a portion of the mergers and acquisition activity we see in the market, that can be helpful in terms of the financing some of that M&A. But otherwise, no, I don't think it really is going to have a big impact.

componenttext: The pricing is -- the pricing opportunities are similar. I think we provide a lot of value in the spec grade market with our research and ratings. But it's also where the marketability of their bonds and the commentary that we offer, I think, provides quite a bit of value to them.

componenttext: Kind of a high level question for you here. So if you look at the S&P 500 medium firm net debt-to-EBITDA come, I think it's at the highest level since 2004. U.S. corporate debt outstanding has gone up by about 50% since 2008. So I guess, given that backdrop and given where we are in the credit cycle, how does your view of corporate leverage kind of influence your medium to long-term view of the issuance outlook?

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe. I think you're right in pointing to the fact that a number of metrics point to a relatively high leverage in the system today. So for this entity, I think what we're more focused on obviously is sort of indicators of credit stress. We're looking at
componenttext: Maybe. I think you're right in pointing to the fact that a number of metrics point to a relatively high leverage in the system today. So for this entity, I think what we're more focused on obviously is sort of indicators of credit stress. We're looking at liquidity and covenant protection and default -- production of default. And there, what we see is a slight uptick. I mean, we've seen a lot of significant movements in energy and mining space and we have a slight uptick in the other sectors, but they remain -- compared to the [indiscernible] standards for controlled. In terms of the size of the debt, what we -- to the extent these companies continue to operate, this will end up to be refinanced, and that's obviously a positive element. And as we've said before, we continue to build our portfolio of credits we have in CFG and that's also positive for this line of business.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We didn't get any further questions on expenses for 2016. And just to make sure that we're level setting, we often comment on the expense ramp at this time of the year and we haven't done that yet, so I want to make sure that everybody's on the same
componenttext:
Yes. We didn't get any further questions on expenses for 2016. And just to make sure that we're level setting, we often comment on the expense ramp at this time of the year and we haven't done that yet, so I want to make sure that everybody's on the same page with that. Over the course of '16, we're looking at expenses to generally ramp from $35 million to $45 million from the first quarter to the fourth quarter. We would caution everyone that expense timing, FX movements and particularly incentive compensation can move that number around, as we've seen in previous years. We'll continue to manage the costs carefully. We have about $50 [ph] million of expense flexibility that we can move on. If we did encounter a more dramatic situation, we could probably about double that, but we're not expecting anything like that. And as the year progresses, of course, those amounts come down. Similarly, we didn't have any questions on the tax rate. We're looking at 32 to 32.5. We can't do exactly the same thing on the tax rate every year, because we are impacted by individual audit results. So we do expect with the U.S. being the balance of our income potentially for '16, that we might have a little bit more to pay on the tax rate. So again, 32 to 32.5. And our CapEx guidance, I think, most of you saw, had moved up a bit, and that is primarily because some of the things that we're doing in technology and real estate as we have said before, which is I just want to make sure that everyone was aware of those numbers so that can fit in your modeling effort. 
So with that, I'll turn it over to Ray.

headline: Moody's Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
